instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00840: What is 820-00840? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.A1708: What is A1708? A1708 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years Mid 2017, 2016 with EMC 3164, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00840, 820-00875..
definitions.CD3215: What is CD3215? This is a USB-C muxing chip responsible for USB-C communication with devices such as the laptop charger. The most common issue this chip is involved in is when a Macbook wonâ€™t charge or the charger is stuck at 5v instead of going to 20v..
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_G3H: What is PP3V3_G3H? PP3V3_G3H is a 3.3v power line that is present when the machine is in a Global System Hardware Off state, and should come on before most other rails so that the USB-C circuitry can be powered for the charger.
definitions.PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO: What is PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO? PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing/charging chip. This can be shorted to ground by the capacitor on its line, and when this happens, the chip can stop functioning which causes the charger to not turn on..
definitions.PP3V3_UPC_XA_LDO: What is PP3V3_UPC_XA_LDO? PP3V3_UPC_XA_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing chip. When this is missing, either a capacitor on the line has shorted, PP3V3_G3H is missing, or the CD3215 is bad..
definitions.PP1V1_UPC_XB_LDO_BMC: What is PP1V1_UPC_XB_LDO_BMC? PP1V1_UPC_XB_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing/charging chip. This can be shorted to ground by the capacitor on its line, and when this happens, the chip can stop functioning which causes the charger to not turn on. This can also be missing if the CD3215 chip itself is bad..
definitions.PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOD: What is PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOD? PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing chip. When this is missing, either a capacitor on the line has shorted, PP3V3_G3H is missing, or the CD3215 is bad..
definitions.PP1V1_UPC_XA_LDO_BMC: What is PP1V1_UPC_XA_LDO_BMC? PP1V1_UPC_XA_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing chip. When this is missing, either a capacitor on the line has shorted, PP3V3_G3H is missing, or the CD3215 is bad..
definitions.3V3_G3H: What is 3V3_G3H? This is one of the first power rails that must turn on for Macbooks that use USB-C for charging. This power rail powers the CD3215 chip that controls the USB-C charger, speaks to the USB-C charger, and requests 20 volts up from the default 5 volts that the USB-C charger puts out when initially connected to an unknown device. .
definitions.PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOA: What is PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOA? This is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing/charging chip. This can be shorted to ground by the capacitor on its line, and when this happens, the chip can stop functioning which causes the charger to not turn on. This can also be missing if the CD3215 chip itself is bad. Each CD3215 in the system needs to be functioning in order for any of them to speak to the charger and negotiate receiving 20v from the charger rather than the default 5v that a USB-C charger puts out before communicating with the system. .
definitions.U5000: What is U5000? This is the System Management Controller(SMC) in macbooks from 2013-2015.
definitions.U6903: What is U6903? This chip is responsible for creating PP3V3_G3H in 2016-2018 model Macbook logic boards.
definitions.D6905: What is D6905? Diode sitting between PPBUS_G3H/PP18V5 charger voltage and PP3V42_G3H power supply input on very old Macbooks(before 2011), can die and cause PP3V42_G3H to be missing and have no input voltage. .
definitions.C6990: What is C6990? Capacitor to ground on input to PP3V42_G3H power supply. PP3V42_G3H power supply turns 18.5v from charger or 8.5v-12.5v PPBUS_G3H from the battery into PP3V42_G3H. This capacitor can short to ground and keep PP3V42_G3H from turning on which would keep the machine from having a light on the magsafe charger.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> stuck at 5.19V 1.42amp
threads.message:
hello i have <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> no power water damage around areas <CHIP>U8400</CHIP> <CHIP>U7650</CHIP> f4800 j6100
all big coils has no short circuit except L8060 and L7900 their diode to ground is 0.0090
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> .004v 0.396
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> 2.2V

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H_UPC_XA</SIGNAL> | <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H_UPC_XB</SIGNAL> 2.2v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_UPC_XA_LDO</SIGNAL> | <SIGNAL>PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO</SIGNAL> 3.3v
<SIGNAL>PP1V1_UPC_XA_LDO_BMC</SIGNAL> | <SIGNAL>PP1V1_UPC_XB_LDO_BMC</SIGNAL> 0.0v
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_XA_LDOD</SIGNAL> | <SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOD</SIGNAL> 1.8V

there is no water mark on the other side of the mother board where is <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP>

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> stuck at 5.19V 1.42amp
threads.message:
"<SIGNAL>PP1V1_UPC_XA_LDO_BMC</SIGNAL> | <SIGNAL>PP1V1_UPC_XB_LDO_BMC</SIGNAL> 0.0v"
Only one appears at a time; depends where the charger is connected.

Compare diode mode readings on LDOs between both <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> chips.
<SIGNAL>3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> correct voltage is required, to get 20V at USB-C ports.
1.42A consume is very high for 5V input.

<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> stuck at 5.19V 1.42amp
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> stuck at 5.19V 1.42amp
threads.message:
So voltage drops when connect <RESISTOR>R6999</RESISTOR>.
Post dioe mode to ground on <RESISTOR>R6999</RESISTOR> pads (resistor removed).

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> stuck at 5.19V 1.42amp
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> stuck at 5.19V 1.42amp
threads.message:
Check if <RESISTOR>R6999</RESISTOR> is really 0 ohm.

Possibly corroded capacitor on <SIGNAL>3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> rail.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> stuck at 5.19V 1.42amp
threads.message:
i didnt see any corroded caps on <SIGNAL>3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> asside from pin no:2 on j6100 
is it posible the <CHIP>U5000</CHIP> is the fault? if yes is it changeable?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> stuck at 5.19V 1.42amp
threads.message:
A thermal cam can help you.
1.42A at 5V is approx 7W.
Compare the current cosumption w/ and w/o <RESISTOR>R6999</RESISTOR>.

threads.message:

with <RESISTOR>R6999</RESISTOR> current consuption is 0.600
without <RESISTOR>R6999</RESISTOR> is 0.050 drops to 0.034 
after performing this with or without <RESISTOR>R6999</RESISTOR> <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> is 0.0V

threads.message:
"1.42A at 5V after injecting <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>"
You've stated 1.42A on thread title; didn't mention about such voltage injection in first post.

Post again <CHIP>U6903</CHIP> voltages.

threads.message: <CHIP>U6990</CHIP> all 0v just notice when i remove again <RESISTOR>R6999</RESISTOR> pin2 diode to ground is 0.0028 almost full short.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> stuck at 5.19V 1.42amp
threads.message:
Remove <CAPACITOR>C6990</CAPACITOR>/1 (one by one) and check.
If still short, change <CHIP>U6990</CHIP>.
You may need to change <RESISTOR>R6906</RESISTOR> and/or <DIODE>D6905</DIODE> too.
